title: Comparison of immune response to influenza vaccine in transplant patients and healthy controls

producedBy.name: Comparison of immune response to influenza vaccine in transplant patients and healthy controls

studyGroups.name: 6 month post-transplant subjects receiving trivalent influenza vaccine

values: Subject had renal transplant 6 months prior to start of study.
Healthy subjects not receiving immunosuppressant drugs and are age, gender and race matched to patients.

values.value: Our projects seek to improve our understanding of the biological mechanisms that underlie the distinct immunosuppressive regimens in practice today (calcineurin-inhibitor, or CNI-, and sirolimus-based regimens) and in emerging regimens that employ agents with novel mechanisms of action, such as the CD28 costimulation blockers, and/or JAK3 kinase inhibitors.  Such knowledge will be critical to strategies for enhancing desirable immune responses while not precipitating rejection. We are undertaking three complementary studies: Study 1: Characterization of the impact of CNI-based, sirolimus-based, and novel immunosuppressive regimens on protective immunity over time in renal transplant recipients, Study 2: A prospective comparison the magnitude and character of the immune response to influenza vaccine in defined transplant populations and healthy aged-matched volunteers, and Study 3: Responses to and control of vaccinia in immunosuppressed Rhesus Macaques.   http://projectreporter.nih.gov/project_info_details.cfm?aid=7337888&icde=23823658&ddparam=&ddvalue=&ddsub=&cr=1&csb=default&cs=ASC

primaryPublications.title: Rapid cloning of high-affinity human monoclonal antibodies against influenza virus.

primaryPublications.title: Broadly cross-reactive antibodies dominate the human B cell response against 2009 pandemic H1N1 influenza virus infection.

dimensions.description: FCM experiment to measure frequency and phenotypic profile of B and T cell subsets in renal transplant patients and healthy controls

distributions.title: Comparison of immune response to influenza vaccine in transplant patients and healthy controls

description: To determine the effects of chronic immunosuppressive therapies on the magnitude and character of the adaptive immune response to influenza vaccination.
